body:
I have no idea whether this is a bug in SFML or a bug in your window manager.

Reading [this](http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/xcb/2012-September/007865.html) and [this](http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/xcb/2010-June/006133.html) makes me think that it's 50/50. I'm leaning more towards the bug on the WM side since on all the systems/WMs I tested, the string is always null-terminated.

We could still add this check for safety reasons though, but the question now is what to do with all the other strings that are queried in the code. Theoretically they might also not be null-terminated on certain systems as well.
Possibly wrap everything in one non-exported helper and retrieve the strings there with lengths just to be sure?

My window manager is marco (metacity fork for mate).

After a quick search about xcb it seems that they don't care that much anyway (here for example http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/xcb/2012-September/007866.html) and since the actual length is easily retrivied it might worth checking it indeed.

I pushed a quick example using std::string after @MarioLiebisch comment: https://github.com/kode9/SFML/commit/f6e776ff4c43dc9a4a370c353dd0581ccd82e8c9

I didn't see any other location where strings are quiered through xcb. I don't know about other platforms though. Anyway I pushed another commit with a sf::String constructor taking a length parameter, seems a good thing to have.

issue.title: Fix undefined behavior in ewmhSupported()
issue.body:
Fixes #892

I'll let @eXpl0it3r decide whether this gets into 2.3.1 or 2.3.2. :stuck_out_tongue:

issue.title: WindowImplX11.cpp incorrectly assumes xcb_get_property_value returns null terminated strings.
issue.body:
AddressSanitizer detects a buffer overflow in WindowImplX11.cpp.

Code Sample:

``` cpp
#include <SFML/Graphics.hpp>

int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
    sf::RenderWindow window(sf::VideoMode(200, 200), "SFML works!");
    return 0;
}
```

**AddressSanitizer stack trace:**
==20008==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on address 0x6040000094b4 at pc 0x7f6cb126869b bp 0x7ffc07c2dc20 sp 0x7ffc07c2d3c8
READ of size 5 at 0x6040000094b4 thread T0
    #0 0x7f6cb126869a in __interceptor_strlen /build/gcc/src/gcc-5-20150519/libsanitizer/asan/asan_interceptors.cc:531
    #1 0x7f6cb0b1ea5d in sf::String::String(char const*, std::locale const&) /home/jeff/Code/sfml/SFML/src/SFML/System/String.cpp:72
    #2 0x7f6cb0d55fe0 in ewmhSupported /home/jeff/Code/sfml/SFML/src/SFML/Window/Unix/WindowImplX11.cpp:235
    #3 0x7f6cb0d576f4 in sf::priv::WindowImplX11::WindowImplX11(sf::VideoMode, sf::String const&, unsigned long, sf::ContextSettings const&) /home/jeff/Code/sfml/SFML/src/SFML/Window/Unix/WindowImplX11.cpp:579
    #4 0x7f6cb0d4ed82 in sf::priv::WindowImpl::create(sf::VideoMode, sf::String const&, unsigned int, sf::ContextSettings const&) /home/jeff/Code/sfml/SFML/src/SFML/Window/WindowImpl.cpp:71
    #5 0x7f6cb0d4e344 in sf::Window::create(sf::VideoMode, sf::String const&, unsigned int, sf::ContextSettings const&) /home/jeff/Code/sfml/SFML/src/SFML/Window/Window.cpp:124
    #6 0x7f6cb0fcca1c in sf::RenderWindow::RenderWindow(sf::VideoMode, sf::String const&, unsigned int, sf::ContextSettings const&) /home/jeff/Code/sfml/SFML/src/SFML/Graphics/RenderWindow.cpp:45
    #7 0x401708 in main (/home/jeff/Code/sfml/bug/main+0x401708)
    #8 0x7f6cafee078f in __libc_start_main (/usr/lib/libc.so.6+0x2078f)
    #9 0x4013e8 in _start (/home/jeff/Code/sfml/bug/main+0x4013e8)

**System Details**
OS: Arch Linux
Compiler: GCC 5.1
Desktop Environment: KDE

**Code Causing the Problem**
WindowImplX11.cpp Line 233-235

``` cpp
const char* name = reinterpret_cast<const char*>(xcb_get_property_value(wmName.get()));

windowManagerName = name;
```

As far as I can tell, the source of the problem is [strings returned by xcb_get_property_value are not null terminated](http://xcb.freedesktop.org/XcbRationale/).  By chance there is a '\0' character after the string, but it lies outside the allocated structure.  A humorous side effect of this is AddressSanatizer only detects the overflow if the length of window manager's name is a multiple of 4 (because otherwise the terminating null character would fall within an allocated word of memory.)
